t: Job 33
Elihu Claims to Speak for God
“However*pn now, Job, please hear my speech, And*ln listen to all my words.
Behold*ln now, I open my mouth, My*ln tongue in my mouth speaks.
My*ln words are from*i the uprightness of my heart, And*ln my lips speak knowledge sincerely.
The*ln Spirit of God has made me, And*ln the breath of the Almighty gives me life.
Refute*ln me if you can; Array*ln yourselves before me, take your stand.
Behold,*ln I belong to God like you; I*ln too have been formed out of the clay.
Behold,*ln no fear of me should terrify you, Nor*ln should my pressure weigh heavily on you.
“Surely*ln you have spoken in my hearing, And*ln I have heard the sound of your*i words:
‘I*ln am pure, without transgression; I*ln am innocent and there is no guilt in me.
Behold,*ln He invents pretexts against me; He*ln counts me as His enemy.
He*ln puts my feet in the stocks; He*ln watches all my paths.’
Behold,*ln let me tell you, you are not right in this, For*ln God is greater than man.
“Why*ln do you complain against Him That*ln He does not give an account of all His doings?
Indeed*ln God speaks once, Or*ln twice, yet*i no one notices it.
In*ln a dream, a vision of the night, When*ln sound sleep falls on men, While*ln they slumber in their beds,
Then*ln He opens the ears of men, And*ln seals their instruction,
That*ln He may turn man aside from*i his*i conduct, And*ln keep man from pride;
He*ln keeps back his soul from the pit, And*ln his life from passing over into Sheol.
“Man*ln is also chastened with pain on his bed, And*ln with unceasing complaint in his bones;
So*ln that his life loathes bread, And*ln his soul favorite food.
His*ln flesh wastes away from sight, And*ln his bones which were not seen stick out.
Then*ln his soul draws near to the pit, And*ln his life to those who bring death.
“If*ln there is an angel as*i mediator for him, One*ln out of a thousand, To*ln remind a man what is right for him,
Then*ln let him be gracious to him, and say, ‘Deliver*ln him from going down to the pit, I*ln have found a ransom’;
Let*ln his flesh become fresher than in youth, Let*ln him return to the days of his youthful vigor;
Then*ln he will pray to God, and He will accept him, That*ln he may see His face with joy, And*ln He may restore His righteousness to man.
He*ln will sing to men and say, ‘I*ln have sinned and perverted what is right, And*ln it is not proper for me.
He*ln has redeemed my soul from going to the pit, And*ln my life shall see the light.’
“Behold,*ln God does all these oftentimes with men,
To*ln bring back his soul from the pit, That*ln he may be enlightened with the light of life.
Pay*ln attention, O Job, listen to me; Keep*ln silent, and let me speak.
Then*iln if you have anything to say, answer me; Speak,*ln for I desire to justify you.
If*ln not, listen to me; Keep*ln silent, and I will teach you wisdom.”
